Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Thermodynamic and Structural Mechanisms in Protein Fold Adaptation and Thermostability

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

Understanding how to redesign enzymes to function at different temperatures is critical to increasing the efficiency of many industrial processes including the production of biofuels. It is also crucially important to understanding the basic principles of protein folding, adaptation, and stability. This project tests and applies two novel hypotheses in protein adaptation and stability: 1) that protein adaptation is "Fold-Specific," meaning that the molecular adaptation strategy taken to alter an enzyme's temperature range is dependent on its specific enzymatic fold and 2) that increases in the stability of the native state of a protein can be achieved by limiting the conformations accessible in the unfolded state through steric exclusion of non-native like conformations - a novel mechanism termed 'Entropic Stabilization.' Already, many mutations that have no apparent effect on the folded state structure have been observed to increase thermostability, and the hypotheses stated above are proposed as a fundamental mechanism to explain this phenomenon.

In the process of testing these hypotheses, several enzymes (alpha-glucosidases and cellulases) in the most common protein fold, the 8 stranded alpha/beta barrels, will be redesigned to function at the high temperatures consistent with the needs of promising industrial processes. Using high throughput, low error rate, random mutagenesis and chromogenic selection, several enzymes which show increased thermostability will be selected. In order to achieve higher catalytic rates and efficiencies, enzymes from psychrophilic, or "cold-loving," organisms will be used as a starting point. From multiple attempts of this process, a structural map of "hot spots" in the alpha/beta barrel architecture that show a high probability of involvement in temperature adaptation will be generated. These "hot spots" will be compared to those identified from a structural database, developed by this project, of all known alpha/beta barrel structures from mesophilic, thermophilic, and psychrophilic bacteria to posit general, fold specific rules for protein design.

In a complimentary approach, those thermostable mutants that exhibit no obvious structural mechanisms for thermostability in the native-state will be compared using hard-sphere steric ab initio molecular modeling to enumerate all possible sterically-allowed conformations for tetra-peptide sequences in the protein. These will be classified as native-like and non-native and will then be compared to similarly calculated conformational space ratios for the structurally equivalent regions of wild-type enzyme and correlated to their propensity for increasing thermostability. In order to classify which conformations are ruled in or out, and which are native-like and non native, a novel 3D Ramachandran Map-like tool that graphically represents different tetrapeptide conformations will be developed.


Broader Impact

In 2009, Forbes ranked Claflin University as the Best Historically Black University in the nation. Over 90% of the student body is African American and 60% are first generation college students, making Claflin a vital part of the regional and national effort to recruit minority students into advanced degrees in STEM fields. By incorporating this research into four different project-based lab courses at both graduate and undergraduate levels, students will learn traditional techniques such as protein purification, PCR, kinetics measurements, and bio computational analysis, and will apply them in semester-long projects. In order to stimulate enthusiasm, the top-performing students (with the largest number of successful mutants or best computational results) will earn one trip to a national research conference to present their results. Thus, this project encourages over 40 African American and first generation students per semester (all biology and biochemistry majors at Claflin) to participate in and learn about cutting edge bio fuel research. The project will introduce the field to a whole generation of students, while at the same time supporting the development of sustainable energy by unlocking a critical step in biofuel production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes are used in many industrial processes from the making of paper to the removal of pulp from orange juice. They are found as additives in clothes washing detergents, used as medicinal remedies for people with gastrointestinal problems or conditions such as lactose intollerance, and they are used in the production of bio-fuels.

       Bio-fuels represent an important alternative energy source to fossil fuels but their production isnt without problems or costs. The most widely known bio-fuel is ethanol but its production relies on the availability of edible crops such as corn. As fuel needs grow, the increased demand can cause food prices to rise. A less problematic alternative would be using non-edible sources of carbon for these fuels, such as inedible plant material like leaves, grass or similar sources known as cellulose. This project has narrowed in on a specific hurdle in the production of bio fuels from cellulose to increase the efficieny of the bio fuel creation process and lower its cost. It is well known that the process generates a great deal of heat which often destroys the enzymes being used. This can drive up the price of bio-fuels as money must be spent to cool the process to an acceptable temperature. In this project, we have created over 70 variants of the enzyme that all show greater ability to withstand heat. In the process of doing so we have learned about the fundamental nature of how certain types of enzymes adapt to temperature. The enzymes we have studied are part of the largest family of proteins, known as alpha beta barrels.  10% of all known proteins fall into this family. By learning rules on how these kinds of enzymes can be adaptaed to different temperature ranges we are allowing researchers everywhere to be able to more easily adapt their target enzymes to whatever production process they intend to use. 

  An additional outcome of the project has been the adaptation of simulation software that allows us to understand how these mutations or changes to the enzyme allow it to function at the new temperature. This new adaptation of parts of the LINUS software created by George Rose is designed to function on supercomputers and can allow researchers to better understand how enzymes adapt to temperature.

Also as part of this project has been a very ambitious educational plan. The research project was implimented in several iterations of a general biochemistry laboratory course and its accompanying lecture. Students learned the typical things you learn in a biochemistry course only in this instance learned it in the context of a semester long research project - learning how the various steps fit together and how research is conducted as it applies to real world problems. By framing the purpose in the context of bringing down costs in a production process, students also learned how science concepts can be used to improve industry. 

This projects education plan also tested four new teaching strategies. This has been highly successful. Student evaluations of the course and associated lab have consistently yielded ratings of 3.8 (out of 4) or higher with at least 2 semesters of perfect 4.0 ratings. These numbers are derived from cohorts of at least 35 students per class with response rates on evaluation forms of 80% or higher. This indicates that students who are not passing the course are still giving consistently high ratings! Data collection, as part of the education plan, supports this. Students identify that having multiple strategies and multiple mediums in which to learn, significantly affected their ability to grasp concepts. Of the four pedagogical tools delineated for testing in the award, students were evenly divided on the helpfulness of any of the particular pedagogical tools tested indicating that the initial premise- that availability of multiple learning strategies for each important concept would increase learning and retention - was correct.

 

The new technique of Peer Review Scoring (the act of scoring other students problem set and exam responses according to a rubric) was found to increase performance on related exam questions by 12.6%. "Lecture Expertise", the second strategy tested, whereby students record a video of the associated lecture and edit it for science content and make it available to the class, increased performance on related exam questions by 10%. "Peer Teachings", where students record their own 10 minute instructional videos on a covered critical topic created a repository of study materials that increased with each cohort. Students indicated that they found these videos extremely helpful in studying for exams or correcting misunderstandings in related content. The Class Scribe, whereby one student takes and posts notes for the class was indicated to be helpful by about 20% of students who felt their note taking skills increased. Several of these methods are being incorporated into other courses in the university.
